column1:
commodity /kəˈmɒdəti/
Examples: farmers sell their commodity crops at the market; the company's stock rose as the commodity prices increased,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Anything movable (a good) that is bought and sold.

snub /snʌb/
Examples: I hope the people we couldn't invite don't see it as a snub.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A deliberate affront or slight.
column2: A sudden checking of a cable or rope.

column1:
snub /snʌb/
Examples: He snubbed my offer of help.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To slight, ignore or behave coldly toward someone.

impetuous /imˈpɛtʃuəs/
Examples: she acted impetuously without thinking about the consequences; the manager's impetuous decision led to a major mistake,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Making arbitrary decisions, especially in an impulsive and forceful manner.
column2: Characterized by sudden violence or vehemence.

column1:
succumbed 
Examples: Thai culture as in many other Asian cultures, is succumbing to the influence of westernization.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To yield to an overpowering force or overwhelming desire.
column2: To give up, or give in.

column1:
secularized 
Examples: the church was secularized when the pastor left; the country's education system was secularized to promote equality,"Part of Speech: verb

emanates 
Examples: Fragrance emanates from flowers.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To come from a source

flounder /ˈflaʊndɚ/
Examples: flounder; she caught a flounder while fishing; the flounder was cooked with lemon and herbs.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A European species of flatfish having dull brown colouring with reddish-brown blotches
column3: Any of various flatfish of the family Pleuronectidae or Bothidae.

column1:
eminently /ˈɛmɪnəntli/
Examples: Everyone supported the nominee because she was eminently qualified.,"Part of Speech: adverb
Definition: In an eminent or prominent manner.

embroiled 
Examples: Avoid him. He will embroil you in his fights.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To draw into a situation

transfixed 
Examples: transfixed; The actor was transfixed by the beauty of the sunset.  
transfixed; The scientist was transfixed by the complexity of the data.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To render motionless, by arousing terror, amazement or awe.
column2: To pierce with a sharp pointed weapon.

column1:
transfixed 
Examples: transfixed; the audience was transfixed by the speaker's eloquent delivery.  
transfixed; the child was transfixed by the shimmer of the diamond.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Rendered motionless by completely focused attention, rapt, entranced, mesmerized.

visceral /ˈvɪsəɹəl/
Examples: Her visceral reaction to the news shook the room; the artist's visceral depiction of the storm captured the audience's emotions.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to the viscera—internal organs of the body.
column2: Having to do with the response of the body as opposed to the intellect, as in the distinction between feeling and thinking.

column1:
anthropologist /ˌæn.θɹoʊˈpɑl.ə.d͡ʒɪst/
Examples: anthropologist studies human behavior in different cultures; the anthropologist analyzed cultural practices to understand societal norms.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: One who is versed in anthropology.

niche /niːʃ/
Examples: niche; a small part of a larger whole; niche; a place where a particular species lives,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament. Hence, any similar position, literal or figurative.
column2: A function within an ecological system to which an organism is especially suited.

column1:
niche /niːʃ/
Examples: a niched vase,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To place in a niche.
column2: To specialize in a niche, or particular narrow section of the market.

column1:
culminating 
Examples: sentence 1; sentence 2,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: Of a heavenly body, to be at the highest point, reach its greatest altitude.
column2: To reach the (physical) summit, highest point, peak etc.

column1:
stifled 
Examples: The army stifled the rebellion.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To interrupt or cut off.
column2: To repress, keep in or hold back.

column1:
stifled 
Examples: The stifled attempt at reform led to further resentment.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: That has been interrupted, suppressed etc

chastened 
Examples: chastened; she chastened herself after the mistake; the teacher chastened the student for their poor performance.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To punish (in order to bring about improvement in behavior, attitude, etc.)

chastened 
Examples: chastened; she felt chastened when she realized she had made a mistake in front of the group; chastened; the teacher chastened the student for not paying attention during the lecture,"Part of Speech: adjective

provincials 
Examples: provincials; The local community gathers every year to celebrate the provincials.  
provincials; The provincials of the region are known for their traditional crafts.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A person belonging to a province
column3: A monastic superior, who, under the general of his order, has the direction of all the religious houses of the same fraternity in a given district, called a province of the order.

column1:
rigorous /ˈɹɪɡəɹəs/
Examples: a rigorous execution of law; a rigorous winter.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Showing, causing, or favoring rigour

rekindled 
Examples: fire was rekindled after the wind died down; she rekindled the friendship she had lost years ago,"Part of Speech: verb

column2: To be kindled or ignited again.

column1:
maneuvers 
Examples: Joint NATO maneuvers are as much an exercise in diplomacy as in tactics and logistics.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The planned movement of troops, vehicles etc.
column3: (later also) a large training field-exercise of fighting units.

column1:
maneuvers 
Examples: maneuvered the ship through the narrow canal; the pilot executed a precise maneuver to avoid the storm.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To move (something, or oneself) carefully, and often with difficulty, into a certain position.

complacency 
Examples: complacency; the feeling of being satisfied with one's situation despite potential problems; complacency; the state of being overly satisfied or indifferent to difficulties.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A feeling of contented self-satisfaction, especially when unaware of upcoming trouble.

tactile /ˈtæktaɪl/
Examples: tactile surfaces; the texture of the material is tactile, allowing you to feel the ridges.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: perceptible to the sense of touch.

column1:
oar /ɔː/
Examples: He is a good oar.,"Part of Speech: noun

Definition: A type of lever used to propel a boat, having a flat blade at one end and a handle at the other, and pivoted in a rowlock atop the gunwale, whereby a rower seated in the boat and pulling the handle can pass the blade through the water by repeated strokes against the water's resistance, thus moving the boat .

oar /ɔː/
Examples: oared through the calm lake; the fishermen oared their boat to the shore,"Part of Speech: verb

column2: to travel with, or as if with, oars.

column1:
propel /pɹəˈpɛl/
Examples: propelled the boat across the river; propelled her to win the race,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To provide an impetus for motion or physical action, to cause to move in a certain direction
column3: To provide an impetus for non-physical change, to make to arrive to a certain situation or result.

column1:
bohemian /boʊˈhimi.ən/
Examples: bohemian artist painted vivid landscapes with a passion for creativity; she moved to a small village to live as a bohemian, enjoying the simplicity of life.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: An unconventional or nonconformist artist or writer.

bohemian /boʊˈhimi.ən/
Examples: The bohemian painter inspired many with their unique style; the bohemian lifestyle embraces freedom and creativity.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Unconventional, especially in habit or dress.

bleaker 
Examples: A bleak and bare rock.,"Part of Speech: adjective

attestation /ˈæ.tɛs.teɪ.ʃən/
Examples: attestation; the lawyer reviewed the attestation to confirm the client's identity; attestation; the company required employees to sign their attestation to comply with labor laws,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A thing that serves to bear witness, confirm, or authenticate

obscure /əbˈskjɔː(ɹ)/
Examples: obscure the truth from the students; obscure the details of the painting,"Part of Speech: verb

column6: to make less visible, intelligible, legible, glorious, beautiful, or illustrious.
column7: To hide, put out of sight etc.

column1:
obscure /əbˈskjɔː(ɹ)/
Examples: sentence 1; sentence 2,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: Hidden, out of sight or inconspicuous.

column1:
geodesic /ˌd͡ʒiːəˈdiːsɪk/
Examples: path; a geodesic is the shortest path between two points on a curved surface; in mathematics, a geodesic is a curve that minimizes distance on a manifold.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The shortest line between two points on a specific surface.
column2: (spherical geometry) A segment of a great circle.

column1:
geodesic /ˌd͡ʒiːəˈdiːsɪk/
Examples: traveling across the globe, the geodesic route ensures the shortest path; the geodesic dome is a structure that accurately reflects the curvature of the Earth.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to geodesy.
column2: Of or relating to a geodesic dome.

column1:
deviating 
Examples: His exhibition of nude paintings deviated from the norm.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To go off course from
column4: To fall outside of, or part from, some norm

column1:
assailed 
Examples: Muggers assailed them as they entered an alley.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To attack with harsh words or violent force (also figuratively).

diversions 
Examples: diversions; the team used diversions to keep everyone engaged during the meeting  
diversions; the movie was so popular that it became a major source of diversions for the audience,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A tactic used to draw attention away from the real threat or action.
column3: an activity that distracts the mind.

column1:
menial /ˈmiːni.əl/

Definition: A servant, especially a domestic servant.
column2: A person who has a subservient nature.

column1:

column2: Of or relating to unskilled work.

column2: An insufficiency, especially of something essential to health.

wedlock /ˈwɛd.lɒk/
Examples: wedlock; the couple celebrated their wedlock with a grand feast; the couple's wedlock was tested by the challenges of life.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The state of being married.

bourgeoisie /ˌbʊə(ɹ)ʒwɑːˈziː/
Examples: bourgeoisie; The bourgeoisie controlled the economy during the Industrial Revolution.  
bourgeoisie; The working class fought against the oppressive rules of the bourgeoisie.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A class of citizens who were wealthier members of the third estate.

notary 
Examples: The notary public signed the contract; the notary handled the legal documents for the company.,"Part of Speech: noun

Definition: A lawyer of noncontentious private civil law who drafts, takes, and records legal instruments for private parties, and provides legal advice, but does not appear in court on clients' behalf.
column2: (common law) A notary public, a legal practitioner who prepares, attests to, and certifies documents, witnesses affidavits, and administers oaths.

column1:
ethnicities 
Examples: ethnicities; the festival showcased the vibrant ethnicities of the region  
ethnicities; each country's ethnicities reflect its rich cultural heritage,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The common characteristics of a group of people, especially regarding ancestry, culture, language or national experiences.

elitist 
Examples: elitist politician was known for their ruthless decisions; elitist society values education and culture highly.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: (usually derogatory) Someone who believes in or is perceived as believing in rule by an elite group.

elitist 
Examples: elitist; the elitist judge dismissed the case despite the evidence.; the elitist society values talent over birthright.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to elitism.

contemporary /kənˈtɛm.p(ə).ɹi/
Examples: Cervantes was a contemporary of Shakespeare.,"Part of Speech: noun

column2: Something existing at the same time.

column1:
contemporary /kənˈtɛm.p(ə).ɹi/
Examples: contemporary art exhibition; contemporary music trends,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: From the same time period, coexistent in time.

institutions /ˌɪnstɪˈtjuːʃənz/
Examples: government relies on its institutions to maintain order; her university is known for its strong educational institutions,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A custom or practice of a society or community.
column2: An organization similarly long established and respected, particularly one involved with education, public service, or charity work.

column1:
lucrative 
Examples: A successful career can be lucrative; a lucrative investment can yield high returns.,"Part of Speech: adjective

patriarchal 
Examples: patriarchal; the ancient Egyptian religion was considered patriarchal; the family structure of the medieval European villages was often patriarchal,"Part of Speech: adjective

column3: Relating to a system run by males, rather than females.

column1:
fostering 
Examples: Our company fosters an appreciation for the arts.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To nurture or bring up offspring, or to provide similar parental care to an unrelated child.

fostering 
Examples: fostering a new plant in a greenhouse; fostering a passion for music in young learners,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Raising someone to be an accepted member of the community.

eroded 
Examples: to erode a person's trust,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To wear away by abrasion, corrosion or chemical reaction.
column2: To destroy gradually by an ongoing process.

column1:
eroded 
Examples: bridge; statue,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Worn down or worn away.

palatable /ˈpæl.ə.tə.bəl/; /ˈpæl.ə.tə.bəl/
Examples: For some instant noodles make a palatable, if not especially nutritious, meal.; The agreement was palatable to both of them.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Pleasing to the taste, tasty.

apparent /əˈpæ.ɹənt/
Examples: apparent; the weather was apparent in the clouds; the signs were apparent, indicating the path to the village,"Part of Speech: adjective

column5: Clear or manifest to the understanding

column2: existing or having existed since birth.
column3: Originating in, or derived from, the constitution of the intellect, as opposed to acquired from experience.

Examples: groomed a puppy for its first walk; groomed a player for a competitive event,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To attend to one's appearance and clothing.
column2: To care for (horses or other animals) by brushing and cleaning them.

column1:
groomed /ɡɹuːmd/
Examples: dog; horse,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Having a neat and clean appearance

equate /ɪˈkweɪt/
Examples: sentence 1; sentence 2,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A statement in assembly language that defines a symbol having a particular value.

equate /ɪˈkweɪt/
Examples: She equated the two theories to see if they align. The teacher equated the students' performance with their effort.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To consider equal or equivalent.

barnacles 
Examples: barnacles clung to the ship's hull; barnacles grew in dense clusters on the rocky shore.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A marine crustacean of the subclass Cirripedia that attaches itself to submerged surfaces such as tidal rocks or the bottoms of ships.

barnacles 
Examples: barnacles the sailors used to secure the ship's hull; barnacles the artist applied to create a natural texture,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To connect with or attach.

drudgery /ˈdɹʌdʒəɹi/
Examples: The drudgery of repetitive tasks was unbearable; the workers struggled to keep up. She found the drudgery of daily chores frustrating.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Tedious, menial, and exhausting work.

uncanny /ʌnˈkæni/
Examples: uncanny; the strange occurrences in the village were uncanny; the ghostly figure was uncanny in its presence,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: (Freud) Something that is simultaneously familiar and strange, typically leading to feelings of discomfort
column2: translation of Freud's usage of the German ""unheimlich"" (literally ""unsecret"").

column1:
uncanny /ʌnˈkæni/
Examples: He bore an uncanny resemblance to the dead sailor.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Strange, and mysteriously unsettling (as if supernatural)

grain /ɡɹeɪn/
Examples: We stored a thousand tons of grain for the winter.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The harvested seeds of various grass food crops eg: wheat, corn, barley.
column2: Similar seeds from any food crop, e.g., buckwheat, amaranth, quinoa.

column1:
grain /ɡɹeɪn/
